Genus: Abelia can be deciduous or evergreen shrubs or small trees, with paired or whorled leaves and axillary or terminal clusters of funnel-shaped or trumpet-shaped flowers in summer and autumn, sometimes with conspicuous, colourful calyces
Cultivation: Easy to grow in reasonable conditions; requires a sheltered, sunny position
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings in early summer or semi-hardwood cuttings in late summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Wall-side Borders Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden City & Courtyard Gardens
Pruning: Pruning group 8. May need hard pruning ( Pruning group 6 ) every 3 to 4 years

Genus: Abies are evergreen conifers, often very tall, with whorled branches bearing flattened, linear leaves, often whitish beneath, and on the upper branches, large cones which break up whilst attached to the tree
Aspect: East-facing or North-facing or South-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained, slightly acidic soil
Pests: May be susceptible to aphids and adelgids

Genus: Abies are evergreen conifers, often very tall, with whorled branches bearing flattened, linear leaves, often whitish beneath, and on the upper branches, large cones which break up whilst attached to the tree
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained slightly acidic soil
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Architectural Coastal City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden

Genus: Abies are evergreen conifers, often very tall, with whorled branches bearing flattened, linear leaves, often whitish beneath, and on the upper branches, large cones which break up whilst attached to the tree
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or East-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained slightly acidic soil.

Genus: Abelia can be deciduous or evergreen shrubs or small trees, with paired or whorled leaves and axillary or terminal clusters of funnel-shaped or trumpet-shaped flowers in summer and autumn, sometimes with conspicuous, colourful calyces
Cultivation: Very easy to grow in reasonable conditions although not fully hardy; requires a sheltered, sunny position
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings in early summer or semi-hardwood cuttings in late summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Wall-side Borders City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal
Pruning: Pruning group 8. May need hard pruning (pruning group 6) every 3 to 4 years

Genus: Abeliophyllum are lax, deciduous shrubs with paired ovate leaves and axillary racemes of fragrant flowers with 4 oblong lobes, borne on the bare stems in late winter or early spring
Cultivation: Grows well in a sunny position although flowers and unripe wood may be damaged by frosts in late winter or early spring
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings or layering in summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Wall-side Borders Patio & Container Plants Mediterranean Climate Plants
Pruning: pruning group 5, or pruning group 13 if wall trained

Genus: Abies are evergreen conifers, often very tall, with whorled branches bearing flattened, linear leaves, often whitish beneath, and on the upper branches, large cones which break up whilst attached to the tree
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained slightly acidic soil in full sun with shelter from cold winds
Diseases: May be susceptible to honey fungus

Genus: Abies are evergreen conifers, often very tall, with whorled branches bearing flattened, linear leaves, often whitish beneath, and on the upper branches, large cones which break up whilst attached to the tree
Aspect: North-facing or East-facing or South-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed or by grafting
Pests: May be susceptible to aphids and adelgids
Diseases: May be suseptible to honey fungus

Genus: Acalypha can be evergreen shrubs or trees, or annuals, with simple leaves and catkin-like racemes of tiny flowers, brightly coloured in some species
Cultivation: Grow under glass or indoors in a loam-less potting compost in full or filtered light. When in growth water freely and apply a balanced liquid fertiliser monthly. Water sparingly in winter, keeping barely moist. Can be grown outdoors in fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil in sun or part shade but only in warmer climes
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings in early spring or semi-hardwood cuttings in late summer. Bottom heat will be required
Pests: May be attacked by glasshouse whitefly, glasshouse red spider mite, mealybugs and scale insects

Genus: Acantholimon are evergreen perennials forming dense mats of small, needle-like leaves, with funnel-shaped flowers in short spikes or panicles in early summer
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in very well-drained soil. Suitable for scree bed, or a wall. Established plants resent disturbance
Propagation: Propagate by seed as soon as ripe, softwood cuttings or layer shoot tips
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Gravel Garden Patio & Container Plants Rock Garden

Genus: Abies are evergreen conifers, often very tall, with whorled branches bearing flattened, linear leaves, often whitish beneath, and on the upper branches, large cones which break up whilst attached to the tree
Aspect: West-facing or South-facing or North-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained slightly acidic soil. Spreads with age

Genus: Acanthus are robust herbaceous perennials with handsome, lobed foliage and tall, erect racemes of two-lipped flowers with colourful bracts
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in sun or semi-shade in well-drained but moisture retentive soil
Propagation: Propagate by seed or by division or from root cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Low Maintenance Architectural Cottage & Informal Garden
Diseases: May be affected by powdery mildews

Genus: Abutilon can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, trees, perennials or annuals, with simple or palmately lobed leaves and bell-shaped or bowl-shaped flowers often with conspicuous stamens
Cultivation: Grow as an indoor or conservatory plant or outside as summer bedding in a sheltered position
Propagation: Propagate by seed in spring at 15°C to 18°C, or by softwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Patio & Container Plants
Pests: Can get glasshouse whitefly, glasshouse red spider mite, aphids, mealybugs and scale insects

Genus: Acer can be deciduous trees or large shrubs with paired, often palmately-lobed leaves and small flowers followed by characteristic winged fruits. Many have fine autumn colour, and some have ornamental stems
PlantRange: Caucasus, Asia Minor to N India
Aspect: North-facing or West-facing or South-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in a moist but well-drained soil
Pests: Aphids and horse chestnut scale may be a problem
Diseases: May be affected by verticillium wilt

Genus: Acer can be deciduous trees or large shrubs with paired, often palmately-lobed leaves and small flowers followed by characteristic winged fruits. Many have fine autumn colour, and some have ornamental stems
Aspect: North-facing or West-facing or South-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in a moist but well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed or by grafting
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance City & Courtyard Gardens Architectural Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: Aphids and horse chestnut scale may be a problem
Diseases: May be affected by Verticillium wilt

Genus: Acer can be deciduous trees or large shrubs with paired, often palmately-lobed leaves and small flowers followed by characteristic winged fruits. Many have fine autumn colour, and some have ornamental stems
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in a moist but well-drained soil in a sheltered position
Propagation: Propagate by seed or by grafting
Pests: Aphids and horse chestnut scale may be a problem
Diseases: Verticillium wilt may be a problem

Genus: Acer can be deciduous trees or large shrubs with paired, often palmately-lobed leaves and small flowers followed by characteristic winged fruits. Many have fine autumn colour, and some have ornamental stems
Aspect: East-facing or South-facing or North-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Grow in a moist but well-drained soil
Propagation: Propagate by grafting or softwood cuttings
Pests: Aphids and horse chestnut scale may be a problem
Diseases: Verticillium wilt may be a problem

Genus: Acer can be deciduous trees or large shrubs with paired, often palmately-lobed leaves and small flowers followed by characteristic winged fruits. Many have fine autumn colour, and some have ornamental stems
Aspect: East-facing or North-facing or West-facing or South-facing
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained, humus-rich soil with shelter from cold, drying wind
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Architectural Cottage & Informal Garden
Pruning: Pruning group 1, from late autumn to mid-winter
Pests: May be susceptible to aphids and scale insects
Diseases: May be susceptible to verticillium wilt and honey fungus
